Yes, The Criterion Collection is known for popularizing many classic and landmark films among cinephiles and film students. Some of the most notable films that The Criterion Collection has brought to a wider audience include:

1. The Seven Samurai (1954) - Directed by Akira Kurosawa, this epic Japanese film is often considered one of the greatest films of all time. Its influence can be seen in countless other films, including The Magnificent Seven.

2. Breathless (1960) - Directed by Jean-Luc Godard, this French New Wave film is a revolutionary work in cinema history. It's known for its stylistic techniques, including jump cuts and handheld camera work.

3. The 400 Blows (1959) - Another French New Wave classic, this film directed by François Truffaut tells the story of a troubled young boy in Paris. It's often considered one of the essential films for students of film.

4. The Rules of the Game (1939) - Directed by Jean Renoir, this film is a biting critique of French society in the years leading up to World War II. It's known for its complex characters and intricate plot.

5. Persona (1966) - Directed by Ingmar Bergman, this Swedish film is a psychological drama about two women who develop a strange and intense relationship. It's known for its enigmatic and surreal style.

6. Tokyo Story (1953) - Directed by Yasujiro Ozu, this Japanese film is a poignant and deeply moving portrait of family life. It's often considered one of the most beautiful films ever made.

7. Rashomon (1950) - Directed by Akira Kurosawa, this film tells the story of a murder from multiple perspectives, each contradicting the others. It's known for its innovative use of flashbacks and nonlinear storytelling.

8. Seven Samurai (1954) - Directed by Akira Kurosawa, this film is widely considered one of the greatest action films ever made. It tells the story of a group of samurai who protect a village from bandits.

9. The Seventh Seal (1957) - Another Ingmar Bergman film, this Swedish classic tells the story of a knight who plays chess with Death in order to prolong his life. It's known for its lyrical and philosophical themes.

10. The Night of the Hunter (1955) - Directed by Charles Laughton, this film is a suspenseful and visually stunning thriller about a preacher who terrorizes two young children. It's often cited as one of the greatest films ever made.

These are just a few examples of the many iconic films that The Criterion Collection has helped to popularize among cinephiles and film students. By providing restored versions of classic films and special features that explore their historical and cultural significance, The Criterion Collection has become an invaluable resource for those who are passionate about cinema.
